ai-ud2.2:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-ud2.2:1.3_0: Now at that time, after the meal, on return from alms-round, several mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them:
ai-ud2.2:1.4_0: “Which of these two kings has greater wealth, riches, treasury, dominion, vehicles, forces, might, and power: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Māgadha or King Pasenadi of Kosala?”
ai-ud2.2:1.5_0: Now this conversation amongst those monks was left unfinished.
ai-ud2.2:2.1_0: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall,
ai-ud2.2:2.1_1: and after going, he sat down on the prepared seat.
ai-ud2.2:2.3_0: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
ai-ud2.2:3.1_0: So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about when the Buddha arrived. The Buddha said,
ai-ud2.2:3.2_0: ‘Which of these two kings has greater wealth, riches, treasury, dominion, vehicles, forces, might, and power: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Māgadha or King Pasenadi of Kosala?’
ai-ud2.2:3.3_0: “This was our conversation that was unfinished when the Buddha arrived.”
ai-ud2.2:4.1_0: “Mendicants, it is not appropriate for you gentlemen who have gone forth in faith from the lay life to homelessness to talk about such things.
ai-ud2.2:4.2_0: When you’re sitting together you should do one of two things:
ai-ud2.2:4.3_0: discuss the teachings or keep noble silence.”
ai-ud2.2:5.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud2.2:6.3_0: is worth even a sixteenth part
